title: 113_hr2292
content:
The Act is named the "Protection from Rogue Oil Traders Engaging in Computerized Trading Act" or the "PROTECT Act." It amends the Commodity Exchange Act to include requirements for high frequency traders of commodity futures and options. The "PROTECT Act" requires registration for high frequency traders engaging in defined activities, along with testing computer programs and establishing safeguards for proper function. The "PROTECT Act" mandates registration for high frequency traders and requires safeguards for program function, messaging and trading activity, risk limits, and market monitoring. It also prohibits simultaneous buying and selling of the same commodity contract unless in de minimis quantities. The "PROTECT Act" requires high frequency traders to register with the Commission, submit periodic sales reports, and provide semiannual reports on trading activities. Traders must also adhere to business conduct standards set by the Commission to prevent fraud, manipulation, and disruptive practices. The Commodity Futures Trading Commission must define high frequency trading activities within 9 months of the PROTECT Act's enactment. This includes registration, sales reports, and adherence to business conduct standards to prevent fraud and manipulation. Fine for high frequency trading violation must be based on the duration of the violation, determined by the number of seconds it continued. Civil penalties under the Commodity Exchange Act are also addressed. The Commodity Futures Trading Commission has the authority to define the scope of violations and assess civil penalties under the Commodity Exchange Act. The Commodity Futures Trading Commission can impose significant civil penalties for violations under the Commodity Exchange Act, including fines of up to $10,000,000 for individuals and triple the monetary gain or losses for others involved in the violation. The Commodity Futures Trading Commission can impose civil penalties for violations under the Commodity Exchange Act, including fines of up to $10,000,000 for individuals with prior violations or criminal convictions related to the Act. The Commodity Futures Trading Commission can impose civil penalties for violations under the Commodity Exchange Act, including fines of up to $10,000,000 for individuals with prior violations or criminal convictions related to the Act. In subsection (d) (7 U.S.C. 13b), penalties have been increased to $1,000,000 for individuals and $10,000,000 for entities per violation, with the option to triple the monetary gain or losses caused by the violation. A person may face triple the civil penalty amount for a violation under the Commodity Exchange Act if they have previously been found to have recklessly or willfully violated the Act or convicted of a related criminal offense within 5 years. The civil penalty for violations under the Commodity Exchange Act can be up to $1,000,000 for individuals and $10,000,000 for entities, or triple the monetary gain or losses caused by the violation. The civil penalty for violations under the Commodity Exchange Act can be up to $1,000,000 for individuals and $10,000,000 for entities, or triple the amount if the violation is willful or reckless within 5 years of a previous violation. Additionally, there can be actions taken to enjoin or restrain violations. In paragraph (1), a civil penalty in the amount of $1,000,000 for individuals and $10,000,000 for entities can be imposed for each violation. Additionally, penalties can be tripled based on monetary gain or total losses caused by the violation. The Act allows for civil penalties of up to $1,000,000 for individuals and $10,000,000 for entities per violation. Penalties can be tripled if the violation is willful or reckless, or if the person has a history of violations within 5 years. Criminal penalties are also outlined in Section 9(a) of the Act. (e) Criminal Penalties.--Section 9(a) of the Act is amended to increase the maximum penalty to $10,000,000 for entities per violation. 
(f) Statute of Limitations.--An action for enforcement of any civil fine must be initiated within 10 years of the claim first accruing, if the offender or property is within the United States for proper service. SEC. 5. EFFECTIVE DATES. The amendment for high frequency traders takes effect 9 months after enactment. Penalties provisions take effect 15 days after enactment.
